Nah. If I convince a few more people to share the core ethos & start using Bitcoin to improve their ability to store & transfer money around the globe, if I learn, discover, & teach a few more things about the nature of money, then I will consider my further efforts a success.

The people who don't share the core ethos of Bitcoin yet are trying to control it, we do want to scare them away. They should go throw their money and noise at some utopian chain. That has worked in the past and I hope it still works. But I agree let's be nice to everybody else.

It is the people throwing around their money or titles (e.g. CEO) to try to control Bitcoin, despite lacking those important areas of knowledge, who properly draw the ire of knowledgeable Bitcoin proponents (not just maximialists).

As far as I can tell, Bitcoin maximalists are only rude in contrast to the faux-village niceness pursued by utopian marketing campaigns that depend on phony friendliness to seem to work rather than on a technology and governance philosophy that actually works.https://twitter.com/aalexis1234/status/984604586215395328 …

Bitcoin reduces the consequences of disagreement via an ethos against hard forks & minimizing acceptable reasons for soft forks, i.e. only for the most important software upgrades; legal or accounting or similar reasons are unacceptable abuses of the software upgrade process.https://twitter.com/richiekp101/status/984551786454413312 …

This does not mean, of course, that it is not in fact an insult (a mostly inaccurate and unfair one, IMHO) to Bitcoin maximilists as individuals or as an ideology, since both individuals and ideologies generally benefit from being polite.

The reverse also holds -- a successful global blockchain attracts people who don't trust each other & thus more likely rude. So saying "Bitcoin maximilists are rude" is actually a complement to Bitcoin. If they think it's an insult to Bitcoin they don't understand blockchains.
